awd_titl_txt: Managed Migration and the Value of Labor
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. David Griffith (East Carolina University) and Dr. Ricardo Contreras (East Carolina University), along with collaborators Dr. Elizabeth Juárez Cerdi (El Colegio de Michoacán) and Dr. Kerry Preibisch (University of Guelph), will undertake research on the sending community effects of managed migration (guestworker) programs. There has been a global increase in managed migration programs; therefore, increasing numbers of guestworkers from Mexico and Central America have had the opportunity to experience United States and Canadian labor markets and work regimes.  At the same time, however, many families across Latin America are struggling to maintain traditional livelihoods, such as fishing and farming, based on domestic production -- household economic operations that draw on family labor and are oriented toward the maintenance and reproduction of the domestic unit and its supporting cultural traditions and social institutions.  The co-occurrence of workers who sell their labor in North America and workers who work in traditional contexts provides an exceptional opportunity for a comparative study of work, labor values, and well-being.

Working with a multinational team in Mexico and Guatemala, the researchers will investigate how the migrants' experiences compare to each other and to others in their home communities, with a particular focus on how they understand and value labor. The researchers' overarching question is whether the experience of selling labor in Western labor markets affects the culturally based economic logic of how labor is valued at home.  The research will be carried out in four communities that have a range of domestic producer operations (artisanal, farming, and fishing) and also send large numbers of guestworkers to the North American labor markets. The researchers will gather data using a combination of qualitative research methods, including: community mappings, several time-staged phases of interviewing, focus groups, transect walks, and cultural domain analyses employing cultural consensus testing, sentence frame tasks, and pile-sorting tasks.  

Findings from this research will contribute to social scientific theorizing of the relation between economic activities, culture, and social well-being.  The focus on nonmonetary values attached to labor is important in light of the current global economic crisis, which has challenged prevailing economic logic. Understanding how labor in different kinds of economic operations produce happiness, dignity, and social legitimacy can assist policy-makers across both North America and Latin America in promoting economic alternatives that have beneficial individual and social outcomes and in developing more effective managed migration programs.  Funding this research also supports international research collaboration and education.

por.por_cntn:
Project Goals: Comparing different forms of labor to one another and, specifically, to foreign contract labor in two regions in Guatemala and two in Mexico, we have been examining relationships among different forms of labor and three indicators of well-being: happiness, social legitimacy, and dignity.  Our goal has been to understand how factors other than wage rates and working conditions influence well-being among people with multiple livelihoods, specifically asking how they value different forms of labor relative to foreign contract labor.

Activities: We completed major portion of the fieldwork for this project in two communities in Guatemala and two in Mexico in the summer of 2016, completing in-depth interviews with 40 individuals per community (160 total) along with multiple cultural consensus, photo voice, pile-sorting, and other more structured interviews on smaller samples of around 15 to 20 per community.  We have been analyzing these data with the assistance of Atlas.ti and SPSS, along with a technique of organizing interviews by themes related to happiness, dignity, and social legitimacy. 

We have made additional visits to the field sites to meet with local research assistants and elicit feedback on the data we have analyzed, and will continue with this work even after the end of the project, given the close relationships we have developed with some of our informants.  Our latest visit was in March 2017, but we anticipate visiting guestworkers who come to North Carolina and Virginia to work in the crab houses over the summer of 2017 as well. 

Late in the summer of 2016, we held a memorial conference at the University of Guelph for our co-investigator who died of cancer in January 2016, Kerry Priebisch, at which Griffith presented some of the results of the project that could not have been accomplished without Kerry.  A second conference, a day later, was held at Wilfrid Laurier University in Waterloo, Canada, at which Griffith also spoke. 

Significant Results: From our initial analysis, we have identified ten forms of labor that we are currently analyzing in more detail, considering in particular how they are intertwined with one another, how each is related to managed migration, and how each generates value in the form of indicators of well-being, including happiness, dignity, and social legitimacy but also more conventional repositories of value such as a child’s education, housing, clothing, appliances, gifts, etc.  The ten forms of labor range from reproductive/ affective labor in households to extreme forms of wage labor such as foreign contract labor in the context of the U.S. and Canadian guestworker programs that about half of our informants participate in—range, roughly, along a continuum from the moral economic labor seated in family and community to the political economic labor separated, as far as is possible, from family and community.  At the moral economic end of the spectrum is reproductive/ affective labor and at the political economic end is foreign contract labor in the context of guestworker programs, which separate productive from reproductive labor nearly completely. 

 

We anticipate that continued analysis of these forms of labor will seriously question conventional ideas about the value of labor, particularly those that calculate value based on labor market principles and neoclassical economics ideas of individual decision-making.  Engaging the anthropological and social scientific literature on value (e.g. Nancy Munn, David Graeber, Terrance Turner) is somewhat more helpful, but ultimately focused more on value emerging from exchange and the symbolic dimensions of value rather than value generated by social relations of production and reproduction.  We argue that it is the context of social relations of production and reproduction that value originates and becomes expressed in happiness, dignity, and other positive characteristics.  In preparing some of these initial findings for publication, for example, we focused on the relationship between reproductive labor and foreign contract labor, demonstrating how the two borrow value from one another and result in happiness, dignity, and social legitimacy of workers even in cases where they are working in jobs that many consider hazardous, difficult, and unpleasant. 

In addition to completing data collection and initiating the analysis, we have given four presentations on the project and submitted one article to American Anthropologist, which received positive reviews and a revise-and-resubmit editorial decision.  We resubmitted the revised version May 15, 2017, and are awaiting the editor’s decision.  In addition, we presented material related to the project to the American Academy of Arts & Sciences in Cambridge, MA on April 21, 2017, as part of an invited conference on the Children of Immigrants.  We have submitted a paper based on that presentation to conference organizers, who are currently seeking a publisher.
